column3: Super nice mall! I really like it here, between the shops and all the restaurants in here, it really is a great mall. Tons to do even in the area, highly recommend checking it out!

Had a great shopping experience here whilst on holiday in beverly hills. Went on a Tuesday morning so it was nice and quiet. Lots of designer shops but I fell in love with macys and got lots of designer labels at knock down prices so was able to bring home lots of pressies for the grandkids. Staff were super helpful in there too

High end products at a premium price. Getting around was a bit confusing at first, especially if you enter via the shop fronts, but we got to where we needed to be. The whole feel of the place is a almost like it isn't finished yet - and the food court is small and unappealing.

column2: Very big but missing a lot
column3: We spent a few hours circling the mall and found some great shopping, but there are a lot of main stream shops missing from this place, considering the size, I would have thought it could have had more variety. No real bargains to be had, but that isn't what this shopping centre is all about. This was our high end shopping day and it was the right place for that.
Great shopping experience!!! Nice selection of stores! We really enjoyed the ease of parking as well as exiting the mall. Found some really great deals, wasn't overpriced like one would imagine!
I love this place after the renovation, I miss the food court my son love to visit Panda Express Everytime place is great.

Both I and my wife are frequent visitors to this one-of-a-kind Shopping Paradise, thanks to the Conceirge, Mr. Sammy. Over the course of last few years, we have seen him cater to the clients' needs with much calm, cool dexterity. Not only him, but the young team of Service personnel display an identical attitude, thanks to the constant watch he maintains.Coming from Canada a few times a year, we enjoy the hspoitality of some of our close friends here. What Sammy does, with his captivating smile, is take our enjoyment of the trip a few notches up.Please make it a point to say Hi to the people at the Conceirge Desk, and ask for Sammy. Who knows you might end up receiving a few wonderful gifts, depending upon the value of your purchase in the Center.

column2: One of the best malls in LA.
column3: The shopping is great it's beautiful inside. Even if you don't shop there, this mall is still worth seeing.

The newly redecorated BEVERLY center has lots of places to sit. It‚Äôs very bright. The stores are the most expensive, Tiffany‚Äôs , Prada, etc. although uniglo is on the top floor. The stores have the most bizarre shoes, fun to look at, probably uncomfortable to wear. Not crowded on a Friday afternoon.the apple store is huge and popular.

What a placeWhat a clean placeYou can find all the shops you needYou can eat or drink coffeeYou can park your car with a small amount of moneyLike a dollar for an hour the first hour and then a dollar and a half for every hour

This is a huge beautiful mall with tons of great stores- and bargains too. Download the Beverly Center app for a directory of stores and then see where the closest parking is. You will save yourself a ton of walking by parking correctly.
Beautiful high-end mall. Many shops and restaurants. Did some shopping and walked around. There were many restaurants that I wanted to try but didn‚Äôt have enough time so hopefully next time.

as you would expect after a $500 million renovation. We were mostly around the H & M store on the top floor but it gave me an excellent opportunity to notice the huge screen on that end of the mall. I found out that it is a 35 foot tall LED screen. Showing between the paid advertisements were some amazing computer generated artwork that looked "alive". Kept my interest for a few minutes.Other than that, it is just a shopping center.

column2: Big place with mostly high-end stores
column3: I stopped off from my hop on/hop off bus tour from Hollywood and Highland. I was there early morning and there weren't that many people in the place. I had trouble with the new elevators - you had to pick your floor before you got in the lift and the lift kept taking me to wrong floor. I think when they get their food court, they may get more customers.

column2: Beverly Hills shopping, but there are much bigger malls
column3: The mall is nice, but you have to pay for parking, although not overly expensive. Not to my liking. I prefer the larger malls, such as South Coast Plaza.

I always stay in West Hollywood when I travel to LA. This mall is very close to most of the West Hollywood hotels, and worth coming to even if you‚Äôre not staying in the area. It‚Äôs a big mall with a Bloomingdales and Macy‚Äôs. Across the road is Beverly connection, with all the outlet store like Ross, Nordstrom rack and marshals.between the two you could spend the whole day here. There are a few eating establishments within the mall. It‚Äôs a very nice clean mall in a very nice area.
The mall is nice, but in many ways only the name and location give it an added special touch. I enjoyed shopping at Bloomingdales, and bought a few items.

In addition to Rodeo Drive, this offers some nice indoor shopping. Recently redone, very open and clean. Has the high end couture and also the traditional mall stores. Nice view of Beverly Hills from the huge glass windows!

column2: Ok mall in the Centre of LA
column3: Lots of parking spaces and stores like Victoria‚Äôs Secret, Michael Kors, Ralph Lauren and Macy‚Äôs. If you‚Äôre tired of the typical tourist streets this is a calm mall to visit. Since it‚Äôs located In Beverly you should bring your large wallet...

I've been to the Beverly Centre a few times now and since the recent renovations, it is a beautiful mall and easy to navigate. It has all the stores you would expect and some good food options. But it could have more food variety and a bit more ambience. It was quiet each time I was there and felt a bit sterile.Good for shopping, not great for the vibe.
My favourite shop is Bath and Body Works as the soaps are üëå.i love it so much! I would definitely go back again to all the shops üè¨
Nice place to hang out with the family and have some shoppingWe loved itAmong the shops U can find a supermarket - target

is a huge mall, they have a bit of everything for all likesfrom expensive brands to cheap oneshuge parking garage and a really cool elevatorif you have time and want to do some shopping defiantly check it out

column2: The worst architectural remodelation I have seen.
column3: Nice on the inside, terrible remodeling on the outside. Not a single interesting food place/area. Who was the mastermind? What a waste!
Very good shopping and dining place. There are most of the highend brands, parking was very easy location excellent

A large mall for window shopping only because most of the shops are way to expensive. The atmosphere is cold...would not recommend it. I went to the grove after this and that wasn't that big but way more fun.

If u really want to have perfect shopping, They have a lot of luxury stores and they‚Äôre usually pretty private since not a lot of people shop here. I mostly window shopped at the expensive retail stores. the only busy store was the apple store. all I can say this is one of the largest and luxurious malls I'm visiting. and a good advantage is the mall is not so busy so the noise level is very low. the parking garage is very quite, no service people were there I guess. I used my instapark app to parking my car. the food is actually very costly...You‚Äôll most likely have to go to a restaurant in the area if you want good food. There‚Äôs a ton of options across the street at the Beverly connection,

This mall is in a very fancy area or LA. It‚Äôs been under construction for a VERY VERY long time so there‚Äôs always certain areas of the mall that are closed off.LUXURY SHOPPING:If you are looking for upscale shopping, this is perfect. They have a lot of luxury stores and they‚Äôre usually pretty private since not a lot of people shop here. Weekdays are pretty quiet and weekends don‚Äôt get super crowded.BUDGET SHOPPING:If you‚Äôre on a budget and want stores that aren‚Äôt too expensive, then you have your H&M, forever 21 and macy‚Äôs. Honestly, there‚Äôs a lot of other malls in the area that are waaay better if you‚Äôre on a budget and you really want to shop.FOOD:The food court is still under construction so your food options are LIMITED. You‚Äôll most likely have to go to a restaurant in the area if you want good food. There‚Äôs a ton of options across the street at the Beverly connection, so just go outside of the mall and explore your restaurant options.PARKING:If you‚Äôre here longer than 1 hour then you have to pay. It‚Äôs kind of annoying because stores don‚Äôt validate, one the restaurants. Parking isn‚Äôt too expensive, I believe it‚Äôs around $3-4.FINAL TIP:It‚Äôs cool to check out if you‚Äôve never been, but it doesn‚Äôt have the greatest variety of stores. If you really want to shop, there‚Äôs better malls outside of LA that you can explore. (Topanga Mall, Fox Hills Mall, The Grove, etc.)

We took escalator after escalator to get to the shopping. The view of the city is pretty awesome. We mostly window shopped at the expensive retail stores. The only shop that felt busy was the Apple Store. It was interesting‚Äîlike visiting Rodeo Drive but with much easier parking.

The mall went through some multi-million renovation only to end up looking almost exactly the same with a new coat of paint on it and some minor unnoticeable enhancements. It looks enpty, cold, and like a dinosaur. Sorry but the best mall now and even before their renovation is the Century City Mall. I was expecting so much from this very long renovation but its so underwhelming and almost exactly the same looking as it was before. Gosh, I wish they would have just given me the money as a consultant because I could have told them in a second thar this was going to fall flat as it apparently has. Yes there are new restaurants around there but as far as stores or shopping I would just rather go to Century City mall.

The store line-up seemed ok but found nothing interesting upon visit. Was it because it was past Christmas that I found the mall stores bare? Went thru Macy‚Äôs , Bloomingdales, Saint Laurent, L‚ÄôOccitane, Bath & Body Works. Didn‚Äôt bother checking other stores anymore.

column2: Not really the Beverly Center's fault, but....
column3: I used to love the Beverly Center, I really did. I never really cared for the Grove - to much tourism, too many people.Yesterday was my first visit after their remodeling (which was really a nightmare). I like the new design from a designer standpoint, found it cold and unwelcoming though.And unwelcoming it was - first I was shocked when I parked - no one there? I was wondering: is it closed? Then: no people. Not that I really mind, I was not looking to find new friends/ company, but to buy three things:A: A nespresso machine at Macy's - a cyber monday dealB: The iphone XS or RC: Shoes for my wonderful wife :-)Again no people = bored staff = everyone playing with some sort of mobile devize instead of giving possible customers a welcoming look to make the come in. Shoes first: the sales lady did even bother to look up. We felt so unwelcome, almost as intruders. We left.Then: coffee machine at Macy's. We were the only customers there, to sales reps. We asked for a specific machine - one had no idea what she was doing. The "Breville Nespresso Creatista Single Serve Espresso Machine with Milk Auto Steam Wand" in black was on display and I asked her if this model was also available in "Champagne". She shrugged - had obvoiously no idea what she was doing there. Shje helplessly looked to her colleague, who said in a harsh Russian accent to "come back later". We left.Finally: my wife and I want to get new iphones. We went to the Apple store - possibly the busiest store in the mall, but far from being really busy. We were greeted by three important looking guys with mobile devizes to "check us in". I asked if someone could help us to decide between the iphone XS and XR - sure, there are five people in front of me - just give us 30-60 minutes. As we had a business dinner at Cleo (around the corner) in an hour, I asked if he or any of the two others could quicky explain the difference I was whisked off - come back when you bring enough time.They must have lost their mind.We left the Beverly Center, bought shoes in an owner operated boutique oin our way to Cleo ando ordered the coffee machine from Amazon. I am seriously considering busing a Google Pixel phone.

On first appearance it looks huge. To start the lifts are confusing you have to enter your destination before u get in at the outside controls quite confusing. Although spread out and quite a few designer stores not make international high street brands. Shops I hadn‚Äôt heard of and even Victoria Secrets although spreads out was not as much selection as would have liked. Macy‚Äôs menswear you have to enter through the ground floor street level or there is one lift that gets you there but quite confusing. Not many food places or coffee shops to stop and get something. Disappointed yes Bloomingdales and Macy‚Äôs are there but struggled to find things to buy.

Largest mall we have ever been to and have visited many large cities. Larger than the Fashion Show Mall in Las Vegas. Every upscale shop you can think of is there. Shops are on all different levels. Macy's has a men's store and a women's store.
All the big luxury brands can be found in this mall. It‚Äôs a bit expensive as opposed to other same brand stores outside but nevertheless if you want Louis Vuitton etc you can find it all here.

This is a very well maintained big shopping center down in Beverly hills. Beautifully designed with a nice inside decor. Almost all brands have shops at this center in addition to two department stores (Macy's and Bloomingdale's). Luckily shops were on sales when we visited so we did some shopping. Unfortunately during our visit last July some elevators linking Macy's men stores to other floors were not working so we had to cross the parking area to reach other stores.

The Beverly Center has some amazing shopping. You do have to take several escalators to get from the parking garage to the stores but the variety of stores is worth it! The 3-D Holographic wall was cool and kept my kids entertained while I shopped! The concierge workers were not very helpful so we figured things out for ourselves. Was located in close proximity to our amazing SLS hotel!
It is tough enough to get in and the lifts are a pain. There is limited food and drink places that are decent and when you have a shop round the selection is so so and over priced.

I have been here many times over the years, but it doesn‚Äôt seem to be in prime shape anymore.There were quite a few shops closed and they seem to be doing some work in the centre, but it‚Äôs mystique of being a high end shopping destination seems long gone.

column2: Needs a huge amount of work - avoid the lifts!
column3: I visited this mall with my small child in a pram after going to The Grove (which is gorgeous). The parking is easy and not many people were there. However the parking is very misleading. It appeared to advertise 4 hrs for $1 but it actually cost $6 for around 2 hours.The centre is huge and is located above on a great number of floors from the carpark. The lifts are a safety hazard. The ones closer to Macy‚Äôs were out of order and the ones near the information desk were busy with lots of people waiting. You had to put the floor you were going to into a touch screen and then wait for your number to come up. They don‚Äôt work! We waited ages and then got taken to the wrong floor then up and down and eventually got out on another floor to start again. It was very stressful and I would never visit there again while I have a child in a pram. Imagine when the mall is busy!When I visited there were only 2 cafes operating - one on the top floor and one on a lower floor. The vending machine near to Macy‚Äôs was suggested by the customer service at the information as being the best option for a drink. Except that that was out of order as well.All in all I was extremely unimpressed with this centre.

I recently visited Beverly Center and was very pleased with the range of stores. Even with construction on multiple floors, the 3(ish) available stores had a wide offering. There were a lot of higher end stores out of my price range (Versace etc.) but also plenty of more affordable stores (H&M, Forever 21 etc.). Across the road is Beverly Connection which has a good range of discount/outlet stores too. Will be brilliant when the food court opens.

column2: Great place to shop in the heart of West Los Angeles
column3: Easy place to find parking. Bright and airy inside. I found a lot of stores under once roof. Food was available on all levels. There are even restaurants with views of the LA basin. While the Macy;s is there so is the other stores to explore. Combination of food, entertainment, and shops. Better than the open air maills in the heat and smog..

Want a cold drink on a hot LA day, searching here is pretty daunting with no food court that could be found and sparse options, most of which were crowded because we weren‚Äôt alone on our mission. The usual mix of high-end stores with Bloomies & Macys as anchors; the top level seems to be for the younger less extravagant crowd, with H&M, Forever & Uniqlo among the options. Lots of space to walk around; very poor wayfinding; hardly anyone around to ask info of...and a slippery floor.
This is the beautiful center in whole of Los Angeles. The center is very clean and very safe. It is shoppers paradise.

very good shopping, went there on our very first day of our holiday's and our sons nearly brought all ther cloths on the first day of the trip in Macy's, we found the staff helpfull and polite. It was very clean and tidy.

column2: Good shoping place at beverly hills
column3: This mall has all the big and normal brands and huge apple store. One can shop here more conviently then rodeo drive

column2: One of the worst malls ever.
column3: The mall is one of the smallest I ever been to. They got the high end brands like LV and Burberry but other than that it is small and not much of a gallery.

Welcome to Hollywood welcome to Beverly Hills Beverly Center. The center just spent 500 million dollars on a restoration and a remodel. Incredible that they pick the color white to paint the outside my grandmother would have picked a better color.This can be a fun place you're going to need to have comfortable shoes you're going to be doing a lot of walking.Everything inside the mall is expensive from clothing to food going to the movie theater or any kind of entertainment. Make sure you take out a bank loan or call your credit card to extend your credit limit before you enter the mall.As I was strolling around the mall one day with my wife I use the restroom to wash my hands and found the bathrooms filthy toilets overflowing and a disgusting smell in the restrooms. This did not happen on just one occasion this is many occasions on different days so it's obviously the left hand does not know what the right hand is doing.Parking is at a premium better to park outside of the mall in public parking which is a lot less expensive than you're going to pay when you get to the mall.Shoppers beware especially if you're coming to California for a summer vacation pickpockets are at an all-time high best to travel in a group of people or with a friend to prevent this from happening to you.I'm trying to think why anyone would want to go to a mall that is so expensive. If you want to say you were there take some pictures by a postcard and send it to Grandma.One ‚òÜ Star Rating
They seem to be half way through some refurbishment at this mall. Maybe that's why it was so deserted. There are many lovely shops, full of staff but very few customers. Strange place.

column2: Great Shopping for those of you, who own a "Blackcard"...
column3: Definitely an experience for shopper's who can shop without looking at the price tag! I was grateful to give my son this experience, he was literally floored when he saw a pair of Robbin Jeans at $700.00 that was on the low-end....

Visiting on holiday, we got a cab to the Centre, what a waste of a fare!!. The main escalator was off and being repaired!!, Half the Centre is just boards and no sign of shops coming. If it wasn‚Äôt for Maceys and Bloomingdales we would have been in and out in 10mins. There isn‚Äôt even a coffee shop in any of the levels!. We left and walked to ‚ÄòThe Grove‚Äô and had much nicer afternoon.
This huge mall has Bloomingdale and Macy's under the same roof. Besides very good and beautiful stores. It'was.very practical for us, being tourists and having no time for shopping

The best shopping mall in Los Angeles. Everyone who likes to go shopping is right here. You get everything you want here. No matter if you like technique or clothes, the selection is extremely good. The security staff will help you even if you can not find a shop.
Could not believe that in this area was free parking for two hours, worth a look just to see the expensive shops. If your on a budget do not eat around here as not cheap.

Sadly, this is a dying place. Even though the mall has attempted to be refurbished, it's not that well done.The elevators are ridiculous: be sure to hit the button of what floor you want on the OUTSIDE of the elevator, not the inside ! How random and odd is that.The mall has a terrible layout. Smoke parking that was free on Sunday, so I'd say lark there and go elsewhere!I hope this is helpful.

I am not sure if they are finished with the upgrade of the Beverly Center, however, it looks like a car grille or something from the outside. It is not very appealing. Inside it is like a Ghost Town with not too many shops open and no atmosphere. It is difficult to find food, not functional or easy to make your way around the center and to add insult to injury they charge you for parking with no validation. Definitely skip this place and head to the Grove.

Every year that we go to USA, we visit the Beverly Centre. The range of stores is excellent and the Godiva Chocolate Shop is my personal favourite! Macy's is excellent and we have found that on weekends in December, they seem to do special 'friends and family' discounts. The only negative comment I have is that the layout can be quite confusing. Some elevators only access certain parts of certain levels and it is very easy to get lost. Even my husband who swears that he has a documented 'allergy' to shopping loves the Beverly Centre.

column2: Wasn't aware going thru quite a bit of construction
column3: I always love going shopping here but this last time was a bit odd. Didn't seem to be near as good and the construction is a HUGE inconvenience. The Lacoste store and some others do not seem to be there any longer as well?

column2: Can't find food in shopping area
column3: Arrived at 11:30am hoping to find an early lunch. Only found a pretzel stand in the shopping areas above the parking levels. Other restaurants are on the first floor. However, One place was not open till later, one under construction, and the one restaurant open had a long line. Across the street I saw a strip mall with lots of restaurants open. My 6 year old boy was hungry. We ended up at Farmer's Market.When they finish the proposed eateries, I may return.

column2: Hope the reconstruction update is worth it...
column3: The whole block inside and out was under construction. I took public transportation from the location where I was staying downtown and I had to alter the order of my errands because of the street construction surrounding BC. There is no better way to test a person‚Äôs patience than with scaffolding, construction workers, and dust everywhere. I was on a mission to shop a specific store I knew was in BC‚Ä¶I had to walk up a ramp through the parking structure because the closest entrance through a department store was blocked. Even though there isn‚Äôt much foot traffic at the northwest corner, it was kind of a buzz kill to enter this way. I had to find what floor and the location of the store. There was scaffolding everywhere and in some ‚Äúhallways‚Äù the lighting was so dim it was eerie and maybe just a little unsafe. I found the store I was looking for and made my purchase; unfortunately later during my week in L.A., I looked at my receipt and there was a mistake. I ended up having to go to a different location of the chain store and the mistake was corrected. That store had its own issues, but to speak of Beverly Center, it‚Äôs a fun place to shop when you‚Äôve got the time to contend with but I'm pretty sure its heyday is over; the good thing is the construction won't last forever but it won't be the place to be like it was in the late 1980s.

I usually like shopping at the Beverly Center, but my recent visit was disappointing: dealing with reduced lanes for parking entry, closed off areas while looking for my favorite stores. I shall have to wait until the remodeling is completed to return.

I expected so much more from this mall and was totally disappointed. There is construction going on outside the mall so to get in you had to walk through Macy‚Äôs Men‚Äôs Department to the elevator and then go to the 6th - 8th floors. Sound confusing? It was.I wound up in Bloomingdales which I did like. I won‚Äôt return until the construction is over.

I have been here numerous times and the parking is always chaotic for me. The shops are alright and for people watching, decent place to do so. Under renovation for exterior, I am really not sure it is for the better, not it looks like a prison with wired metal decor. The old look was definitely more futuristic.

column2: Now it is almost finished the renovation its great
column3: The newly renovated Beverly Center is beautiful. Really worth a visit. It has almost all of the upscale stores & many other popular stores too. The two anchor stores are Macy‚Äôs & Bloomingdales

column2: Don‚Äôt forget the Beverly connection next door
column3: Okay, this mall is a large complex with the top two floors for shops on top of multiple floors for parking. It‚Äôs under remodel right now the highlight was to ride the outside escalator for a view of Los Angeles. There are quite a few high end stores here including a Ferrari store.Now next door is the Beverly connection which has what I would call a selection of off price stores like saks off fifth ave, Nordstrom rack, Ross, tj maxx, Marshall‚Äôs and a target. So it‚Äôs not a bad setup for those wanting luxury goods or those looking for deals
Last time I was there the whole mall was under construction, I read that it will go until next year, I couldn't wait to get the hell out of there. Besides that I used to love this place

column2: Definitely a place worth visit for a collection of brand items
column3: Good range of brands from Gucci to Tiffany.Also can hop over to the other mid range mall Beverly Connection selling Gap and Navy across the street.Good area to explore for both range of shopping. Use the hop on hop off bus to get you around for shopping and attractions. You must try the farmers market at the next stop too.

column2: Just A Tad Bit Overrated If You As Me....
column3: The Beverly Center would be a great definition of an overrated mall. It's not a horrible mall but it's also not one that really gives me a "WOW" experience. You hear all sorts of things about shopping out in Beverly Hills and being apart of that whole glamorous scene but it's not quite fulfilling the hype.In the past, I've visited several times both pre-construction and most recently during construction. It's like a war zone right now but the whole renovation was much needed. The question is though will it help enhance a shopper's overall experience? That is left to still be determined. Renovated or not I really hope they implement a better parking situation because my gosh it's a mess to say the least. On my most recent visit my friend and I had to stop by the apple store and it was just an in-and-out type of thing. We couldn't have been here more than 45 minutes and when headed back out through the parking garage it still cost $2?!Yeah, yeah I know... most are probably like why is he shopping at the Beverly Center if he is complaining about $2. My issue isn't about the money but solely around the principal.. Point, blank and the period. Think about it most malls offer some sort of validation when you stay under a certain amount of time. This is the Beverly Center! If people come drop a few thousand dollars they shouldn't have to pay for parking.Bottom line is there are PLENTY of great malls and places to shop while in Los Angeles. You won't be missing out much if you just so happened to not make it to this one lol. I'll possibly visit again once the construction is completely done..

They‚Äôre obviously rebuilding this centre. We‚Äôve never seen so many boarded up shops with no signs of new tenants. Clearly the Center itself is going upmarket. But it was almost a ghost town yesterday. We were dying for a coffee and a small snack. The food court is gone and we couldn‚Äôt find a cafe for love or money. Strange for such a large Center

I would advise you to avoid the Beverly Center until the massive construction project is done. There are still a lot of shops but it isn't really worth the hassle until the renovation is over. Another thing where did all the restaurants go?

My visit to the Beverly Center was short and sweet. There were lots of rich stores here like Prada, Gucci, Armani, etc. If you‚Äôre going to see celebrities, then this is the place to be. The entire mall is under construction but will be a really big mall once it‚Äôs completed. I couldn‚Äôt find a food court and it was a little confusing as to where things were. There are other shops nearby like; Old Navy and Nordstrom.

Currently under major renovation and construction. A lot of shops closed. Very big shopping centre with a huge variety of shops available anything from Maceys & Bloomingdales , Apple, Ferrari etc etc.
Very nice at Hugo boss store service first class w William Ramos I really recommend the store if u like Hugo boss clothes:)

Wasn't aware it was being done up - best to avoid at this point in time - limited entrance points, confusing on how to get anywhere.All the expensive / designer shops are open but the place is empty and is not worth the trip at the moment.Macy's open but as usual looks like a jumble sale, dark, uninviting and just awful - although the staff are really friendly and helpful.

My son and I visited the Beverly Center as there are a nice mix of stores across all price points. It was like a maze because of construction that is underway. The Macy's store was very nicely laid out and our entry point into the center. There are 8 floors but the 2 - 4 floors, I believe, are parking. When coming off the elevator, there are stores that are in a circle, while construction is being done in the middle. Can't wait to see the final product.
A quick tour around popular local and foreign stores and also some good places are just around the corner. Reasonable parking fee.
Hopefully, one day this will be worth the visit. They are undergoing renovations. What is open look fine.

column2: Just drive a couple of miles east or west...
column3: To either Century City, Rodeo Drive, or The Grove. This mall is the worst in terms of construction, selection of stores and parking (dishonest and shady protocol). Beverly Center is an eye-sore. Elevators skip floors, malfunction parking machines.Century City just renovated and the ambiance is peaceful with hammocks and bamboo decor.Like the other reviewers here... I would skip the Beverly Center. It will be worth your peace of mind.

column2: Under construct but still worth a visir
column3: Ventured here for the first time and really enjoyed the experience. A good mixture of both high and medium end stores as well as Bloomingdales and Macy's. Great choice of both men and women's clothes and felt the centre was clean and well maintained. Staff were also very helpful in pointing us in the right direct to get a taxi.
Definitely not the time to visit. Under major renovation. only parts of some floors open. Only place to get a coffee is Starbucks on 7th floor. Feel sorry for retail tenants.Disappointing.
Not sure if it's because of the renovation, but the place is deserted. No restaurants or cafes, which is a bit weird. Overall, okay but not really impressed by it.

Came into the mall with the hopes to get something to eat and use the restroom in a clean and cool environment.The only place open at this time was Wetzel Pretzels and vending machines. There seemed like two other food places are open at the moment but it was so insignificant to me I don't remember. The Beverly Center doesn't even advertise what is open now, it just boasts about the five places that will open in the future.Many shops are closed. Some that are open are high end. There are also anchor shops like Bloomingdale's and Macy's.Parking was reasonable - $1 per hour. I felt it was easy to navigate around by elevator or escalator.Would return in the future when construction is complete.

column2: As malls go, this is cool, ... BUT!
column3: All across America, malls and large scale stores are closing, or downsizing. It's the "Amazon effect", and while sometimes the convenience of buying online saves time, The Beverly Center is still a place you should go to, if you are in West Hollywood. You can find whatever you need here, because otherwise some things are hard to find, or overpriced. Parking is ample, and if you have kids, this can take up some time in a cool atmosphere. I mean, a mall is a mall, but this is Hollywood.

I went to this shopping centre over 20 years ago and it was very beautiful I went there today and it's very below average there was plenty of renovations going on .. but really nothing to rave on about just that it's in great location.. but for shopping centres it's very very average

column2: Was the gold standard now it's bronzed
column3: Just passed through. Major renovations taking place, and complete disruption. I viewed some renovated parts and they were really nice. But in the end, it wasn't an enjoyable experience so for now my advice is to avoid.
Place is still under construction, lot of shops are closed, some of them working but rarely, should be good once it's finished,
Few stores, poorly laid out. Trying to get back to your car is a gamble with the elevators. I'm surprised it's still open. Huge disappointment.

I was in the area and my teen son wanted to see this shopping center. It us under construction so hard to get around the place...felt like a rat in a maze. Hard to figure out where we were and hard to access any shops. We stayed for 30 minutes max. If you want an excellent shopping experience, visit The Grove instead or 3rd Street Promenade in Santa Monica. See my reviews of those places...Also no restaurants in this shopping center which is odd.

Always enjoy this mall. Although it's under reconstruction at present this is still a great shopping centre and will be even better once completed. All the big brands! Floors so shopping. Directly opposite is Beverly connection with all the outlet stores you need with Ross and Marshalls.

column2: It may be better once it is finished
column3: This is under construction when we came so it was hard to find the stores as the detour signs can be hard to follow. There were great shops there though. 3 levels of shopping fun! We had a Starline 'hop on hop off' pass which allows you to go to the customer service desk and get discounts on certain stores. I would recommend this
Still under mega reconstruction, as it has been for some while. Better to head to The Grove and other area malls. Really nothing special about it and the scaffolding everywhere is a decided bore!

column2: Stay away for a while...Construction mess
column3: This shopping center was previously great to navigate. The construction is horrible and it is hard to find the entrances and dark inside. The Bloomingdales was a huge disappointment and didn't carry some of the nicer brands that I would have expected in an affluent suburb. The construction makes it impossible to enjoy shopping and dining.

You name it it's here!!! And despite the dust from the remodeling going on, there's friendly staff to guide you around on the inside of your lost! The stores are never-ending....from my fav Louis, to Tiffanys, Gucci, Lacoste, Bloomingdales and Vickis to everything in between! And of course some good ole Starbucks to keep ya pumped n going! It was great!!!

This place is doing some renovation at the moment so it's kinda frustrating to shop especially if you are shipping by Bloomingdales area which is all the construction is. Parking is good but you have to pay for it even though you were there even for under an hour. I'll come back when renovation is over.
All luxury brands are present there. Also non-luxury shopping is posible, you'll find an apple store and a Macy's.Bar from 6th floor I don't recommend it. No great bartenders.Enjoy!
This place was being renovated when we visited and it's already a difficult place to navigate, I really H&M in there, I just don't like going there really, strange place

column2: Lots and Lots To See and Buy!!!
column3: There are more shops than you have time for in one visit! And a good range of prices on apparel and everything else.

Very confusing to get around with the current renovations in progress. What we did like was that the Macy's, Bloomingdales, and fast fashion (H&M, Uniqlo) stores were well stocked and carried a great assortment of men's merchandise. Skip Gucci, Prada and the like as their Rodeo locations carry more variety of stock.
Beverly Center is under going a remodel at this time but you can still shop. Alot of high end stores .

Visited while we were in LA, it was under construction so it was a little messy and unattractive. But let me tell you this, we had zero problem spending money in the stores. I guess once its done its going to be really from what everyone told us.

column2: Great Mall for Higher End Shopping
column3: A high rise mall in downtown Beverly Hills. Lots of specialty higher end stores that you won't find in your typical mall out in the Midwest. We enjoyed looking in many of the shops and bought a few things. Mall was very clean. However, it was under construction when we went but still accessible to all the stores. They offer covered mall parking within the structure. The mall has a food court and is approximately 4 stories of really nice stores. Worth a visit for sure.

We were here last time about six years ago with our whole family and were rather impressed with the structure, the external escalators taking us from the car parking levels to the 6th, 7th and 8th floor shops.Parking was cheap at $1 per hour for the first 3 hours in the multi storey car park. The costs goes up a bit more after 3 hours.This time, there were a lot of renovations going on at the Bloomingdale end and we came out from our elevator to walk through construction tunnels to get to the major shops.The area of the high end European Designer shops were fine. There were very few shoppers about this afternoon. Quite a change from the very busy Westfield at Culver City not so far away.We only did window shopping on this occasion, as my wife having already done some shopping in Europe where prices are lower at the current exchange rate with the Euro and the tax refund on leaving Europe.

column2: Has most of what you need
column3: Array of shops gives you everything from cheap to luxury items.When I visited they where doing renovations that meant that there was no food court.But still a great place to go shopping I Beverly Hills. Atleast for the mid range pricing shops.Clean and nice which also makes it very laidback and nice imo.

Nice upmarket indoor mall. Has all the popular brand stores but be warned, this is not a mall for bargain hunting. The food court could be better but hopefully after the construction work finishes the variety should be better. The car park has a great view of LA & for a tourist looking to past a couple of hours then go check out this Beverly Hills mall.

The Beverly Center has transformed from a basic mall with chain stores to a place for the up-scale shopper with Gucci, Prada, LV stores etc. The dining level with fast food places has been re-placed with higher priced food establishments.

Clean and nice but for shopping... I think you can do better. It's very very high end (outrageously pricey) or teeny bopper (cheap and trend of season-ish). Nothing in between for regular people. I was really wanting to shop, but nothing appealed to me.

The center was still under construction and you had to travel up like 5 escalators to reach the top. All the shops were very expensive as you may of guessed but there was nothing 'special about the place' neither but it did suit my reason of going in it, superdry.

The Beverly center is undergoing construction at this time. It is not a pleasant shopping experience during this phase. You are walking under scaffolding from place to place in dark hallways to get from the parking garage. It seems that the anchor stores such as Macys and Bloomingdales have been reduced to miniatures of themselves during construction. I really wouldn't bother until they re-open to their normal selves.
Shopped here in August and the mail is being redesigned and lots of building works going on but still able to find the stores we were looking for and plenty of range of shops on offer

Yes the mall is huge and they are adding more stores. But if you are looking for things to do on your trip to Hollywood that isn't shopping keep moving.Parking is $1 the first hour and then it charges every 15 minutes. I believe it caps at $17, but I wasn't there that long.If you love shopping then this is a good place for you. There are tons of stores in the Center and even more across the street. The mall is clean and so is the parking structure,.

column2: This mall is huge & still growing!
column3: We went here to pick up one of my brother's birthday gifts. There are so many phenomenal stores & boutiques! And to think, they are still adding on to this beautifully-made building! Several stores had signs up that said, "Coming Soon 2017"). An actual person is located nearby to guide & to answer any questions you might have in reference to the location of any store at the Beverly Center. What a great experience!Ashli H. ‚ù§ ‚ù§ ‚ù§ ‚ù§ ‚ù§
Best place to shop, many type of shops you can find.There is a shop called "Love Culture" that has women and girls clothing that are on trend and in good quality also in valued prices. Should visit.

We have seen it in the movies, and while knocking out all of the tourist attractions had to make a stop since we were in the area. It is a nice mall, with plenty of unique stores. The parking was easy, and we did find a few gifts to bring back to the kids. It was not too busy, but the time of year we hit L.A. does help when you're trying to do the whole tourist thing. It is much more enjoyable to go to Orlando or L.A. when the kids are in school so you have less mobs to deal with.

We valet and went to a store and left. In and out in under 1 hr. It was easy access from valet to the elevators. $7 valet for under 2 hr and the stores with validate with a purchase. The store selections here are good if you are looking for brands but after a store or two, your rent/mortgage for the month maybe be depleted.

This must be the same place to come as a tourist to LA if you want the designer stores. Anchored by Bloomingdales and Macy's this centre has an excellent selection of stores.Car park is huge with easy access to the shopping centre.My complaint is the construction work means shoppers are sent down long corridors that are in desperate need of air conditioning. I hope this doesn't last too much longer.The shopping centre will definitely be a nice place to visit once construction work is complete.
I expected it to be filled with cafes and restaurants but it was too limited. They only had one crowded Starbucks and one restaurant

column2: It is a Huge Shopping Center. Move on.
column3: Beverly Center is crowded and quite large. It is an indoor shopping center. I have no idea why you would go there while traveling in Los Angeles. The eateries are for the most part chains, the stores are the same stores you will likely find at home. If you want to shop go to Wilshire Blvd. in Beverly Hills, park at Nieman's--buy something there and get free parking and then walk the street. That is fun.Beverly Center is a mall. There is not one thing special about it.

column2: Okay shopping center, not all shops I expected
column3: Partially in reconstruction, surprisingly empty even on weekends (people probably spread out due its size), doesn't have all the average shops, more on the expensive side. Another part of the shopping center across the street, couple restaurants as well.

Used to be a busy mall to shop not any more. Lots of shops to see, in door so air conditioning during the summer is great, ask the concierge for store sales and discounts before shopping. Parking is decent and not expensive

This place is amazing! It's a lil on the upscale side but it's very clean, sophisticated, nice stores, great parking.Even the bathrooms and the changing rooms are fantastic. Security is vigilant and the staff is friendly and professional.I loved the fact that some of my favorite stores were located in this mall so for me it was all about convenience :)

This mall has become more high end. If that is what you like then this is the spot. This use to be a more normal mall with a variety of price points. That mall is gone.They do have a good Macy's. But it to is in transition. I used to come to this mall regularly now I come here less.

Don't bother a special place this is not its just another tragic out dated mall. Truly nothing special here. It's got a few high high end designer the rest was just a few sneaker stores. Was very dark inside
All the nice and popular shops where you need them! Great Center with a mixture of upscale and affordable shops. I also enjoyed the food court.
This is a large shopping center located conveniently in West Hollywood. It has a lot of upmarket shops. Best time to shop is when the center opens.

Dark, difficult to navigate. After we entered the Beverly Center, we spent most of our time trying to leave. With others as frustrated as we were, we found navigating the escalators and elevators almost impossible. It's hard to imagine this mall as ever having any appeal for serious shoppers. Perhaps, once shoppers have an established route, this place is manageable. We felt so claustrophobic in this mall, after we left we stayed on the street and continued our shopping in street-side boutiques.

If you are a seasoned shopper, there are many, many more attractive places to shop there here. For Australians, or those that have travelled there, this is like a Westfield shopping mall, but 20-30 years ago, before any of the contemporary renovations. It's a tired, dated centre, that is gloomy and unglamorous. Unless there was a very specific shop you wanted to visit, avoid and go elsewhere.

This a huge shopping mall in Beverly Hills where all high end stores are there like Chanel, Tiffany, Cartier, Gucci to name s few plus a lot of boutiques etc. There are a lot of restaurants and a food court. The whole place is very clean and if you are a tech enthusiast there is a huge apple store in the center. It is a nice place to stop in for browse.

column2: Dissapointing that they no longer have the food court
column3: Was very disappointed to see that the Beverly Centre no longer has a food court, since our last visit the centre has had a refurb and is a little more upmarket with stores and restaurants then when it was more a "Westfield" centre. Opposite the Sofitel Hotel its convenient, but really feel that to lose the food court was a shame.

column2: Old mall that has most things but food
column3: Big mall in LA. But, it has NO restaurants or cafes. They will guide you to restaurants outside if you want to eat. That's odd, that a huge mall doesn't have any inside.The mall looks very tired and old. Needs some new pampering.
Clean with easy parking access. Great stores. Nice department stores as well. Nice restaurants and cafes. I would have lied to spend more time here. Highly recommend.
Mall was really nice. Decent selection of shops. Claimed they were an 8 story mall but only 3-4 stories were shops and the rest was parking. Most of the shops were for higher class people.
A beautifully airconditioned shopping centre with a great view from the escalators to the hills beyond. Offers a variety of shops from Bloomingdales to Macy's and lots in between.

A nice indoor mall with lots of shops. I was pleased to find a Bath & Body Works after searching everywhere! It is also easy to access and has a multi-storey car park so I reckon that parking would be fairly simple.There is a large Macy's as well, along with a range of other clothes shops too.
You would expect an amazing mall because of its name. But its not. Its just average shopping mall. There were literally no people on weekday. It was dry.

Our visit to this place was excellent tour visiting mall and as whole area. We enjoy and highly recommend for exclusive shopping with wonderful arrangements for the people whose priorities are top class than money.

Beverly Center consists of two windowless levels of shops on top of a five-level parking garage. Mall security creates an atmosphere similar to that of the shopping area in an airport terminal.On a recent visit to Beverly Center I was harassed repeatedly by security guards for doing nothing more than writing some personal travel notes. LA is loaded with malls and shopping districts (The Grove, Westfield Century City,Montana Avenue, Robertson Boulevard to name but a few) that are worth your time and money. Beverly Center is not one of them.
Very nice shopping mall within a wide range of stores with varying price points. Something for all budgets there. Parking is easy and the layout is simple to navigate.
Just another shopping mall. Known brand shops with not much choice for restaurant. Won't come back unless i need last minute shopping

visited to kill some time on our last day in LA AND TO GET OUT OF THE hot and humid day.What surprise.A very clean and beautiful shopping center.All the best store from Armani,Macy's,Bloomfield's and even a pleasing surprise ,a Lorna Jane store,a bit of Aussie in this massive City.WE shopped up a storm with all the specials on and a stall everywhere where very friendly.

Not a large mall but it has space inside and confused layout typical of a large mall. Food venues were very limited inside. With that it packs the cosy feeling. Yes many high and middle end shops. Some still being opened. There is a Bloomingdale and Macy's but it's a medium sized department store. So didn't have all the brands and trends like the SanFrancisco union square one.When we did try to look for a balanced place go eat we found California Pizza Kicthen along the road side of the mall.Would I want to visit this mall again. Not really except for one or max two boutique stores.

column2: Go ahead and splurge a little :)
column3: Great place to go shopping when staying at the Beverly Hilton! Has all the major retail chains and high end designers as well. Go browse and there's 3 or 4 levels. Restaurants on site and a Fatburger right across the street!

Parking is a nightmare and you will pay for it. Only the restaurants will validate and nomen of the shops. My biggest pet peeve is paying to park when I am already given money to the mall. Ridiculously arrogant in my opinion. That's the problem (among many) with LA: paying too park even at grocery stores. Just awful.

Really odd experience - empty place with lots of designer shops, a few high street options and a big Bloomingdales and Macys. Very few eating options, generally disappointing and far better alternatives abound (The Grove / Westfied / 3rd Street Promenade). I'll never return.

This mall contains both expensive and affordable clothing so there is something for everyone.The parking is quite cheap, about $3 so shop till your heart's content.This was a pit stop since it was on the way to hotel.Just remember where you parked and you'll be fine.

column2: Nice Selection of Stores in Vertical Mall
column3: I walked to this mall because I had passed it several times and wondered what was inside. It is a nice collection of upscale specialty stores such as Victorinox, Coach, and Stuart Weitzman anchored by Bloomingdale's and Macy's. The anchor stores also seemed to have nice options for shopping. I just bought a foundation in a shade that was unavailable at home. The sales people in all the stores I visited were welcoming. I had lunch at a mozzarella bar in the center of the mall and it was a nice selection of organic greens topped with free range chicken.

column2: Safe and comfortable luxury shopping at the Beverly Centre
column3: Great shopping Centre, all the luxury shops, staying close by enables you to shop till you drop then take your packages to the hotel.

If you're a shopaholic or even just love window shopping, this place is pretty good. But it can get crowded at times, adding to the difficulty of navigating the place. Lots of well-known, high-end shops with some mid-range stores thrown in. It's an enormous building but only the top two floors are shopping (lower floors are parking garage).

column2: Great for shopping and not much as else
column3: I decided to check out the Beverly center because of a few recommendations from a few of my friends. I was already staying in the area, so I figured I'd give it a shot. The shopping is good; a wide selection of everything from high end brands (Fendi and even Prada) to Macy's (which has an outstanding male selection) and other moderately priced stores. That being said, aside from finding a nice Calvin Klein blazer, there wasn't much as to do at Beverly. Nice gallery for stores, but only a few places to eat aside from some high end restaurants.

column2: One stop shop for everything from affordable to high end
column3: Spacious, clean and accessible. Stores are varied from affordable for the cost conscious to the mid-expensive for the fashionista. Best to go mid-week as the weekend crowds can make the place quite congested. Worth a look.

A monolithic, remarkably uninviting edifice that immediately makes you feel like you are being trapped inside a level of Hades. The food court is little more than lots of street vendors clamoring for attention. There was once a movie theater in the complex, but it was so claustrophobic that one would been better off watching a film in LA Country Jail.Don't be surprised it the place is torn down in the very near future.

I don't remember previously that this place was, for want of a better word...rubbish. I does have 2 levels but hardly any shops. There are a few Designer shops, a few places to eat and a large Forever 21 and H&M..there's a Macy's ...other than that...nothing. Also, it's incredibly difficult to navigate...they offer an International discount voucher booklet, but it's not very useful. Strange, I just don't remember it being like this in previous years..try across the street at The Beverly Connection, it's like a mini outlet mall with Old Navy, TJ Maxx and Marshall's discount stores.

Top mall to go to if you are in Hollywood. Easy to get to by public transport. Macy's is the store especially if they have a sale on. We have had big discounts in Kenneth Cole. There is also Bloomingdale's and some high end stores and a decent food court.In the past we have shopped till we dropped although now we are more discerning as we know we shall also shop elsewhere on our trip.
An excellent place to shop and very easy to access. Has quite a great variety of things you would require.
I enjoyed this shopping mall a lot, it was very quiet - and easy to move around the shops. found some great bargains
This shopping center was near our hotel so very easy to get to. Good shops. Loved going to Macys. It was also near a CVS pharmacy and target which was handy for us!
Great shopping outlet. Has stacks of big name brands and a Macy's. Spent quite a bit of time there with my family killing the hours. Clean and safe - well worth a look if you're into shopping.

Easy parking on level of Mall you want to enter at. Bloomingdales, Macy's anchor the store. Many other boutique style shops. Upscale shops to browse. We went on a Mon. evening -quiet. Easy access. Calif. Pizza Kitchen at street level.

As a brit on holiday in LA, I had half a day at this mall and I was speechless as our shopping centres are a lot smaller. So I was pleasantly surprised by the size of the beverley and equally surprised by the amount of shops to peruse. Recommend this.
Lots of "high street" and high end shops. Great if you want to get all your shopping done in one hit. Lots of parking however not much of a food court.
In the heart of the city very close to the Hotel on the LA Cinega.. offer a great variety of brands to choose from basics to decent high end shopping...
There are beautiful shops here, so shopping is fun. It's rather quiet, but not unbearably so. The location is great too, for it's surrounded by a lot of nice restaurants in the area.
Enjoyed our trip to Beverly Center. Didn't buy much but enjoyed shopping in Macy's. The Center was clean and nice to walk around in and if you like higher end shopping it is a nice place to visit.
I love this Mall! You can get just about anything there! I really think thats the best Macys for men.You can get the best deals there.The only downside is there are not enough toilets.
Many different shops, Starbucks, food court. I personally recommend Obika Mozzarella bar.I'd definitely go again.

The Beverly Centre is on La Cienega Drive in Beverly Hills LA, off Wilshire. Easily accessible by bus or car it has two sections.The Beverly Centre has all the big name brands at normal retail prices while across the road there is the hidden gem!! This contains Nordstroms Rack,Marshalls,TJ Max Ross and Target. TJ Max has high end brands at fantasic prices..Michael Kors bags from $120.00 Ralph Lauren,Kate Spade Calvin Klein you name it also homewares and jewellery.Nordstroms Rack has their last season stock at super cheap prices, Marshalls slightly less expensive brands..loads of baby stuff..and shoes..and Ross well Theyre OK. Target is great and also has a supermarket in it. I wouldnt bother with the big outlet malls after going here.There is also a couple of eateries..One is nice cafe style with fast service and great food the other is a all you can eat soup salad pasta and desert bar..For two of us it was $30 with drinks..fresh,tasty well cooked and nice staff. There is free wifi in the centre clean toilets. I bought North Face jackets for $90.00 Opi nailpolish $6.00 for a 2 pack,Ralph Lauren and Juicy Couture outfits for my 2yo grandchild @ $20 each, carry on luggage for $40 a bag...needed them for the excess. Definitely worth going to spend spend spend

column2: Beautiful Mall, if you have lots of money!
column3: I have been to many malls and this is a beautiful one. It is similar to the Mall of Dubai but not as glamorous. All the designer stores are here so it's great to look but probably not to buy. There weren't as many eateries as I expected and I ended up at Starbucks which wasn't even in it's own unit but is just a stall with chairs and tables in the middle of the mall. They do have Bloomingdales and Macy's but it's not the same as visiting these classic stores in NY.

This is a very nice and clean mall. My wife went shopping, and I hung out on the couches. They have nice chairs and couches all around for the "husbands". there is a coffee bean at the Bloomingdales entrance, good to hang around over there.

One of the area's premier shopping malls located at the intersection of San Vicente and La Cienega Boulevards. Taking up a full block, the mall is also near the highly regarded Cedars-Sinai Medical Center and is not too far from the Pacific Design Center. There is ample parking in the Beverly Center's covered parking structure. If you live more than fifty miles away, you may want to stop first at "Guest Services" in the mall to pick up a free "Shopping Passport" which offers special discounts and other shopping offers. The mall features department stores such as Macy's and Bloomingdales and more than one hundred other popular individual stores such as Salvatore Ferragamo, Tiffany & Co., Prada, Fendi, Gucci, and Versace Collection. There are also nice restaurants. "Yeah, uh huh", there is something for everyone.

column2: Large mall with a lot of shopping choices
column3: Most of the mid to high end brands are available here, they don't have a food court any more, I do think that they should allow the shops to validate the parking

Coming from South Africa, where we have hundreds of shopping malls, my daughter and I HAD to visit Beverly Center! A beautiful mall, clean, shiny, airy, light, and opulent. With all the major high-end shops that we don't have here, LV, Prada, Gucci, Apple, Macy's, Bloomingdale's, etc. There was ample parking available, The best place to window-shop, and to look out of the windows at the beautiful view of LA.

When visiting Los Angeles with my 20-something daughter, I knew I had to take her to the legendary Beverly center so she could experience firsthand what big city mall browsing was all about. It didn't disappoint. She really enjoyed the spectacular views of Los Angeles from the expansive windows and was doubly excited to catch a glimpse of celebrity athletes, musicians, models and stars of television and motion pictures, escaping the ordinary, by casually shopping or having a lunchtime bite to eat. First class customer service without a hint of snobbery or puffery. She loved it!

column2: Lots of mid to high end shopping
column3: Tons of Mid to high end shopping stores. Good location to walk around. Clean area easy to navigate to and from. Macys was clean compared to some that I have been in. There is a Nordstrom Rack across the street as well as Marshalls/TJ Maxx. Mall was not overlay crowded, however that could have been due to time and that the president was in town. Took a bit to get there due to road closures from the president's visit. Good place to spend the evening and get dinner.
Good and many shops to buy from. As a foreign tourist, you get a passport at the info desk, with many discount for a lot of shops. They can also provide tickets for basketball, concerts.... Very good
Spacious and well presented mall with sores such asMacy's and Bloomingdales. Food court was closed for renovations.

column2: Best place in town for shopping
column3: You can find many shops as Macy's, Apple, Louis Vitton, H&M and also have a good food at Obika. And it's not crowded mall, go by car because the parking price is good.
The Beverly Center has the same stores as any other mall. We came in to escape the heat and use the bathrooms.
I go to the Beverly Centre every time I'm in WeHo. Great range of shops, easy to get to, close to Santa Monica Blvd

We spent a couple of days shopping here. After the first day, we knew we had to go back. It was my first time at Macy's and Bloomingdales. The staff are truly beautiful souls who made every purchase a delight. We took home some precious buys that will always remind us of the Beverly Center. The restaurants in the mall are few but there is plenty to eat at the ones around. We went back on our last day in Beverly Hills to shop some more!

Probably pricey when compared to other shopping centres however they did have some sales happening.Huge variety of popular culture labels.Convenient location aSome stunning window displays.....and unique edgy stores

column2: West coast fashion in the heart of LA.
column3: This mall is one of our favorite shopping places to visit. Nice stores, easy parking and we always get something that is different from east coast stores. It is often crowded but if you go at right time it will work.

column2: Well, it's better than the Grove ? And closer than South Coast.
column3: Hmmm.. Beverly Center is the "fanciest" mall in LA. They have a lot of new or renovated European designer boutiques. Gucci. Prada. Fendi. Versace. Louis Vuitton. And a big Forever 21. And a mediocre Bloomingdales. And a nice Macy's (really nice men's store). They have closed the food court for a remodel now so there are very few food choices here. Somehow the whole thing seems like the Pompeidu Center had a baby with a crappy mall and left it in the 80s. If you want European designers.. go to Rodeo. If you want Bloomingdales best - go to Century City. If you want Macy's best go to South Coast Plaza. Although the Macy's Men's store at Bev is probably the best thing about the mall and is worth the trip. Oh and I like Henri Bendel for last minute gifts.. The candles are great and unisex. You will see minor celebs..but go to Robertson for better celeb sighting.

It is slick and it is popular, but it is not enjoyable to shop there for luxury goods, even though the merchandise is great. These folks do not understand service and clearly, most of the shoppers aren't there expecting it. Everyone who thinks Rodeo Drive is overrated needs to just compare the service experience between the two. The merchandise (and the prices) are identical. I would rather be treated with consideration rather than being rushed in and out and then being charged for parking. Rodeo? 3 hours free. They get it.
Not an enormous amount of shops, but enough tokeep you occupied. There is something for everyoneand for those who can't find something, there is alwayssomething in the surrounding area.
The Macey's for Men is very good much better than Century city. What's nice about the Beverly Centre is that it is not crowded and directly opposite the Sofitel.

This is a nice mall in L.A. as there are a lot of great stores like luxury brands but also the store Macy's is here. I can recommend Macy's as there is a lot of good offers on a lot brands like Hugo Boss and Levi's. I bought 2 pairs of Levi's jeans for just 85$ - very cheap.
Nice mixture of upscale and stores at every mall but without feeling cheap. Enjoyed browsing and people watching. Parking garage is easy and convenient.

I come from a smaller town and this was the biggest mall I have ever been too. Aside from all of the many stores and boutiques, I loved that one the top floor of the mall, you could eat or just relax out side. There is a great view of the Hollywood sign and downtown LA from the top. I would recommend checking it out.

First of all I am reviewing this as a traveller, from Australia. We obviously don't have a shopping mall like this so me and my husband were completely blown away. It is well appointed with a large amount of stores and was easy to navigate despite us visiting on 'super saturday', the saturday before christmas.

Beverly Center is an ordinary shopping mall. It is on of those mall for shopping only (not having fun as well). Most of the top tier brands have branches in the center (LV, Gucci, Apple store ... etc). There are plenty of restaurants in the area.For pure shopping visit this mall. For fund visit The grove.

I thought based on where the Beverly Center was located it would be a great mall, but actually it's just a mall. Nothing special.I'm sure there are way better malls in LA, in fact the mall near the Santa Monica Pier was even better. As was the Westfield Century City Mall.

This mall is a shoppers paradise with a great variety of stores for men and women and there are some good bargains to be found. There is a good food court to sit and have abide 5o est and do some people watching. This mall is worth visiting for an afternoon.
An American indoor mall at it's best!Great for actual and window shopping!My wife wouldn't leave... Beware guys!
When you visit los angeles you must go To that place. You will have a lot of things To see like great brands great dinner. Enjoy!!
Great shopping experience!!! Nice selection of stores! We really enjoyed the ease of parking as well as exiting the mall. Found some really great deals, wasn't overpriced like one would imagine!
I nice place to spend the afternoon and a little cash. Good Restaurants, shops and funny people to watch.

column2: A hidden jewel of shopping hidden behind a boring white facade
column3: When is the last time you found all your favorite boutiques in one comfortable stroll? Try the Beverly Center! From Fendi, Gucci, Prada, YSL, Burberry, Ferragamo, Tiffany, Dolce and Gabbana, and the most fabulous Montblanc boutique. There are also off beat European designers and great restaurants like Capital Grille and Obika. The biggest Forever 21 in the country and plenty of mainstream shops. Easy valet parking for $7 or self park for $1 an hour. Don't let the outside of the building discourage you... This is a luxury shopping experience all the way.
If you like to shop this is a great centre. Especially if you're into Victoria Secrets clothing, Sunglass Hut and of course the shoe stores. This was our favourite shopping precinct.

This is the high end mall for those who want to spend the big bucks! I loved walking around and admiring the sites. Lots of stores and even a few for the "average person"! But it was fun to see because I like malls and like how to see they are designed. Check it out!

The Bev Center is a Taubman Property and like all Taubman properties its a schlock suburban hell. Its ugly, boring and a total scourge on LA. The shops carry less merchandise than their street-side stores in other areas of town, everything sold in the mall stores is marked up at least 30%, the food is horrible and the security guards have a John Wayne complex when they approach in groups of five or more.I grew up in LA and I know this town better than any other town on earth and I promise you a horrible experience at the Bev Center. Get outside and see the real LA, save some money, and enjoy better, fresher foods.

column2: This is the place for shopping
column3: We spent an afternoon at the Beverly Centre and came away with lots of shopping (Macy's was particularly good) as well as enjoying a meal at Obika Mozzarella Bar. Very enjoyable and reasonably priced.

My friend spent an hour and a half in the mens department in Bloomingdale and then an hour in Macys... quiet mid-week, perfect for us. 4$ for 4 hours parking is very fair. Note the Beverly Connection is across the road for Target, Old Navy, etc: http://www.thebeverlyconnection.com/

column2: WOW, MY HEAD IS STILL SPINNING!
column3: AWESOME, The one word I would use to describe the Beverly Center. This Center has every store that you may have dreamt of going to. This is definitely a high-end ritzy place to be,the best stores one could ask for. Be prepared to do a lot of window shopping because these are not your typical affordable stores( although they may be for most Los Angeles people:-)). There is Luxury all around this area and is second to Rodeo Drive, although there are more stores and you may or may not find a SALE sign every now and then in some of the stores. After visiting the Beverly Center you may wonder if you might want a career change just to be able to afford these wonderful items of fashion.

The Beverly Center is worth visiting, shopping, relaxing at bars or eateries, "just looking" and if one has time, spending hours at the mall. There are the high end shops such as Bloomingdale's, Louis Vuitton, Micheal Kors, Prada, Tiffany and Co., and many, many more. If one's budget requires shopping in typical mall stores, there also are plenty of stores in which to shop. It, however, doesn't cost $$ to walk around and visit any store, regardless of the price of merchandise. Each level has its' own ambiance and stores to match. I very much enjoyed my lunch at Obika Mozzarella Bar (level 6). The service and food were quite good. I ordered a salad of grilled organic vegetables and enjoyed every morsel. It was too early for me to enjoy an alcoholic beverage, however, I will return for a bigger meal and a beverage to match!
I was impressed by the selection here. High end, low end, good snack/food/drink options. Everything we needed all wrapped up in one building. What more could you ask for?
Really nice shops and places to eat.. Really expensive shops, and some not so expensive but it was a really nice place to be.. it was different for an out of towner like myself!
Many stores from the expensive (Tiffanys, Jimmy Choo) to the regular ones (Express, Apple, Macy's).Was a great place to shop on a rainy day

It is not too crowded and great shops including all the major fashion brands. Since I visited there just before Christmas, I had a major shopping spree at Victoria's Secrets and Stuart Weitzman! Great sale! Love the restrooms! Huge Macy's too. Parking is very affordable considering that it is such a high standard shopping center.

Massive range of shops from high end fashion to everyday wear! Im from australia so all stores but Prada and so forth are great value. Much better pricing than back in Australia anyways! Only thing wrong with the Bev centre is the food court, Too healthy give me some fatty takeaways ha!! All in all great shopping experience!
I LOVE LOVE LOVE the Beverly Center!! You can never go wrong in this mall. I could definitely spend at least 5 hours here. All the high end stores are there including YSL, Tiffany and so many others.
Mall not too busy.Very clean and tidy and great customer service!
Very large shopping Center! They have alot of shops to chose from.

If you are looking for top fashion and shops that are full with amazing merchandise to choose from , Beverly Center is your place. You will find your favorite brands there, also it has most designer shops ex Gucci, Burberry, D&J, Fendi, ect...

column2: B Center and new B Connection
column3: Since my last visit and time when I used to live next to Beverly Center, there has been an extension to Beverly Center, the Beverly Connection. I do not know, if they are commercially different companies. B Center has the high end stores and B connection has three interesting chains to visit: Marshalls, Nordstrom Rack and Ross. Also you find Bloomingdales and Macy's at B Center. If you start your day at B Center, you can walk to Grove on 3rd st. Nice 20 min walk.Check in internet the list of stores.

My only gripe was that I went in there to buy tennis shoes and I could not find any. LOL what kind of mall doesn't really sell tennis shoes? Only in LA. I went to Bloomingdales first, they had no athletic shoes unless you count wedges (salesman suggested some athletic looking shoe/wedge hybrid) or metallic coach shoes obviously for styling and not running. Next I tried Macy's which was a horrible mess, it took nearly 10 min to try on my first pair, then I finally gave up and asked the sales person to bring me a 7 in these Pumas that I saw on the floor and that I would take them home without trying them on because I can see at the pace that they were moving that it would take alot longer than I wanted to spend at Macy's. I take the shoes home and with horror realize they gave me UK7 which is a US 10. What a terrible waste of a good shopping day!

column2: Busy one day, Deserted the next..
column3: Went there with my girlfriends a few months ago and it was bustling.. lots of people..All the regular shops youd expect to find at a large shopping centre...The next time I went is was near deserted.. it felt like a different place.. only the Apple store was packed..Dont know why.. .. I had to buy a Chanel lipgloss.. bought it at Bloomingdales .. the shop assistant was a little surly and obviously didnt want to be there.. Either did I after that.. so we crossed the street and went over to Beverly Connection.. lots of bargains to be had there!

Visited the mall, first time after many years.An interesting mix of stores, from high end expensive to lower end value stores and we liked that fact that they are grouped together, so you can shop according to needs and budget.The mall seems a bit old and tired... In comparison to other upscale malls of that level we visited - it needs a face lift sometimes in the near future. Food court needs a major upgrade!
Really just a typical boring mall very cold and impersonal I would recommend the grove which is fantastic or the mall in Santa Monica
great service and not too crowded - everything is there for clothes shopping
Good variety of stores, good opening hours.preferred this to the Grove.

All star showbizz tours has an excellent service with lots and lots of fun....Shellee is the owner of the tours and she is very fun type guide and you would definitely love to be in her tour to bevely hills west holly wood......

Its in a great location so when you get bored of shopping in a commercial mall there are plenty of great shops in the very near surrounding area. I cant complain about the choice and variety of shops, but BEWARE if you are a plus sized person like myself. If require a size larger than L then this is not the mall for you if its clothing you are after. However worth a look.

column2: beverly center has variety of stores
column3: i personally love the beverly center because it has many stores. what i like about the beverly center is that it is for all types of people. the center has stores like american eagle or foot locker, but it also has stores like bloomingdales louis vuitton dolce and gabbana. the beverly cenrter has stores for everyone, from pricy stores to more economic stores.

Hey, I live just down the block from the Beverly Center. This is nothing I'd recommend to a friend. I depends on what you like to do. If you love to shop then this is a good gathering of above average shops. Otherwise I'd skip this and do some hiking or go to the walk of fame since they're so close ...

Visited this mall twice, once in the Summer of 2007 and again in 2008.I preferred it first time round, this time round everything seemed a little more expensive. However there is a fab range of shops and the mall is huge. There is a range of high street, designer and department stores. Also a nice food court on top level.There is a tourist discount book available however both times i asked was told they had ran out!
The mall was very nice and had a great choice of stores to choice from. Whatever you do valet your car. The extra money will save you the extra hassle.

column2: Weird looking from outside, average upscale appearance on the inside
column3: The Beverly Center is a big upscale mall in Los Angeles, California on the border with Beverly Hills. It has a weird design in that the mall sits on top of its multi-level parking garage, making for a giant 14-story-tall monster of a building that towers over the surrounding area.Inside, the mall is rather average, though, and doesn't have any special architectural features that make it stand out from hundreds of other upscale malls around the world.
Just a typical hometown upscale mall, nothin special so don't go out of your way to see it if you already have one back at home.
